content.title: Visceral Artery Aneurysms
content.definition: Visceral artery aneurysms (VAAs) are focal dilations of the celiac, superior mesenteric, hepatic, splenic, or other mesenteric arteries, rare but clinically significant due to rupture risk with potentially catastrophic hemorrhage.

splenic_artery_aneurysm.pregnancy: Rupture during pregnancy carries 70% maternal mortality

hepatic_artery_aneurysm.rupture_pattern: Into biliary tree (hemobilia), peritoneum, portal vein

celiac_artery_aneurysm.treatment: May require aortic reimplantation or bypass

learning_objectives: List relative frequencies of visceral artery aneurysms by location
Identify risk factors for splenic artery aneurysm
Describe rupture risks and management implications in pregnancy
clinical_pearls: Splenic artery aneurysm is most common (60%), associated with pregnancy and portal hypertension
Rupture during pregnancy carries 70% maternal mortality - treat before conception
Hepatic artery aneurysms have higher rupture risk than splenic
Mycotic aneurysms (especially SMA) require urgent treatment
